description.plain: The third and final single from Ethel Cain’s debut album, Preacher’s Daughter. Ethel (aka Hayden Anhedonia) said of the song in a statement with Pitchfork: “Growing up I was surrounded by visions of NASCAR, rock’n’roll, and being the one who would change everything,” Cain said in a statement. “They make you think it’s all achievable and that if nothing else, you should at least die trying. What they don’t tell you is that you need your neighbor more than your country needs you. I wrote this song as an expression of my frustration with all the things the ‘American Teenager’ is supposed to be but never had any real chance of becoming.”

body.plain: The third and final single from Ethel Cain’s debut album, Preacher’s Daughter. Ethel (aka Hayden Anhedonia) said of the song in a statement with Pitchfork: “Growing up I was surrounded by visions of NASCAR, rock’n’roll, and being the one who would change everything,” Cain said in a statement. “They make you think it’s all achievable and that if nothing else, you should at least die trying. What they don’t tell you is that you need your neighbor more than your country needs you. I wrote this song as an expression of my frustration with all the things the ‘American Teenager’ is supposed to be but never had any real chance of becoming.”

translation_songs.title: Ethel Cain - American Teenager (Traducción al Español)

annotations:
Say what you want, but say it like you mean it
 With your fists for once, a long cold war
 With your kids at the front

A cold war is a geopolitical conflict with tension and threats, but stopping just short of actual warfare. Similarly, passive aggression is the expression of negative emotions – like anger or annoyance – through indirect means rather than open communication.

Ethel feels passive aggression lacks conviction, and hopes her dad will “say it like [he] means it” in the one language she was taught to understand – violence.

Neither outright aggression nor passive aggression are healthy forms of expression, but in Ethel’s unsteady upbringing in which healthy communication wasn’t modeled, she is exhausted by the “long cold war” of her dad’s indirect criticism and instead sees violence as a more tolerable alternative.

This could also speak to a larger generational trend of many Gen X and Boomer parents being raised in passive aggressive households and then handing down those hurtful dynamics to their children, thereby putting another generation of children “at the front” against their parents' dysfunction.

Say what you want, but say it like you mean it
 With your fists for once, a long cold war
 With your kids at the front

This highlights the album theme of generational trauma, emphasizing how the problems at hand are not directly recognized by the parents and instead the children bear the grunt of this battle and forced to face this cold war head on. Instead of using direct confrontation (with your fists for once), there is a passive aggressive nature to the struggle between parent and child

And I feel it there
 In the middle of the night
 When the lights go out and I’m all alone again

On an episode of the Lorem Life Spotify podcast, Hayden explained that the pre-chorus was inspired by a memory from her youth where she stayed late out at her high school’s football field. When the stadium lights were shut off, she was left alone in darkness with only her thoughts and a heightened awareness of how ephemeral even the most cherished elements of American culture like the football game truly are.

Putting too much faith in the make-believe
 And another high school football team

Like other southern towns, Shady Grove is a deeply religious community. Since her birth, Ethel is taught to live a life of piety, indoctrinated by her church and late father, Rev. Joseph Cain, who is coincidentally the beloved town preacher.

Despite having such a devout upbringing, we soon learn that Ethel has lost faith in Christianity. Now looking back, Ethel laments that she had built too much trust for religion in her youth when its abuse would cause her so much trauma.

Similarly, high school football is a staple of small-town life in America, with it being common for almost the whole community to come together to cheer on their team. Like her relationship with the church, Ethel regrets growing so much love for the local football team and thus her town when she is hurt by its people and feels like an outcast.
Grew up under yellow light on the street

Ethel lives in Shady Grove, a small, southern Baptist town in Alabama. As a child, Ethel is sheltered under yellow streetlights, too young to recognize the wickedness and hypocrisy of her community.

When asked about her childhood at Shady Grove in a fictional interview with Silken Weinberg, the character Ethel recounts:

Well, it was the same for me as it was for everyone else, I’d imagine. Spent most of my time either at Shady Grove Baptist or playing in the field next to it. Lots of mosquito bites. Lots of cookouts.

Jesus, if you’re listening let me handle my liquor
 And Jesus, if you’re there, why do I feel alone in this room with you?

In spite of being deeply involved in the church, Ethel finds little solace in religion during times of hardship. As we learn later in the album, perhaps she has developed this aversion due to the trauma she has experienced at the hands of her father, or because she’s seen how religion has been abused by others.

Anhedönia herself has trouble finding God, having been crucified by her faith. In an interview with W Magazine, Anhedönia explains:

“It never so much for me was about god. It was more for me about the way people were interacting with each other in the name of god. All of the personal drama was really weird. I was like, god does not even feel like he’s in here. I’m spiritual in my own way now, but Christian religion doesn’t really go further for me than just fodder for my artwork.”

Hands over my knees in a room full of faces
 I’m sorry if I sound off, but I was probably wasted
 And didn’t feel so good
 Head full of whiskey but I always deliver

After her father’s passing, Ethel attempts to preserve his legacy by leading the town’s congregation every Sunday. As we later discover in “A House in Nebraska”, Ethel is also currently devastated that her lover Willoughby Tucker has recently left her, so she drinks to numb the pain. As a result, Ethel often comes to service drunk, but still “delivers” her sermons to ensure that the church runs smoothly.

The neighbor’s brother came home in a box
 But he wanted to go, so maybe it was his fault
 Another red heart taken by the American dream

Ethel reflects on the death of her neighbor’s brother, a soldier who died overseas and whose body was sent home. While she suggests that the brother is responsible for his fate as he joined the army at his own will, Ethel empathizes with him as she realizes that his decision was made in an honorable pursuit of the American dream.

For the brother, becoming a soldier possibly gave him an invaluable opportunity to escape a difficult life at home and earn a stable income, obtain a college scholarship, receive respect from society, etc. Anhedönia thus critiques the harshness of the American dream, where chance alone decides whether one can achieve such incredible success or lose everything in the process.

Interestingly, many members of Anhedönia’s own family have served in the U.S. military.
Sunday morning
Interpolation of Sunday Morning, from Ethel’s 2019 EP Golden Age.
I do it for my daddy and I do it for Dale
Dale Earnhardt, who was previously referenced by Ethel in her song Earnhardt.

song.embed_content: Read “Crush” by Ethel Cain on Genius
song.title: Crush

annotations:
His daddy’s on death row
 But he’ll say it with his chest, though
 His friends move dope
 He hasn’t tried coke
 But he’s always had a problem saying no

Here we see a quick couple of facts that Ethel has noticed about her “Crush.”
She has gathered some observational information about his backstory, it appears as though he has had a troubled past.

His father is on death row for an unknown but most likely heinous crime, and this “Crush” is not afraid to tell people about his fathers doings.
Maybe he thinks telling people about his father will make them see him in a similar light, a tough boy who’s not afraid of anything.

He actively tries to emulate the bad boy his daddy was, possibly in hopes of impressing his circle of friends.

He has a similarly rebellious group of friends, they deal drugs, but this potential love interest hasn’t actually tried doing these drugs himself.

But he seems to be easy to persuade, possibly a people pleaser as he’s always struggled with denying peoples requests. This implies that eventually he might end up partaking in the substance abuse out of the fear of missing out or being deemed not good enough.

Showing up wearing black
 And he knows that

Her “Crush” is lying to the authorities, he’s denying their claims, but Ethel has been closely watching, and knows he is lying, as she even remembers the small details.

She knows he showed up wearing black the day he was shooting, or the day he was keeping guns in his locker.
She remembers the fine details, but he denies those same details to the authorities, even though he knows what he did.
But he lied ’cause I sure did watch him

This is the first hint we get that Ethel has been incentively studying and closely observing her crush.

She’s figured out a couple pieces to his puzzle, and she’s very intrigued by him.
This possibly takes place at a school, maybe he’s a classmate, and she’s been secretly watching him as he gets into more and more trouble.
His mother steady screaming he should be more like him

It seems like this man takes after his father more than his mother.
His mother doesn’t like that, as she seems to be disappointed in both her husband and son for their actions. The mother doesn’t like that her other son, the “Crush,” reminds her of her husband who is on Death Row for an unknown but likely heinous crime.

There’s child favoritism going on here, and however Ethel has been observing this man, she notices these small details and picks up on them.

He has a brother, who is successful, and “bagged” the valedictorian. His mother clearly doesn’t want this “bad boy” son of hers to follow in his father’s footsteps, so she scolds him, possibly after learning about his recent actions.
She doesn’t want her son going down the route his daddy did, and she favors the golden child in an argument.
Hard odds to beat when you’re on all fours

Her Crush lost the fight as he was caught trying to steal. He’s knocked on the ground, on all fours, potentially being beaten. Ethel certainly acknowledges that he lost, but ultimately that does phase Ethel, as she has rose-colored glasses on, and still sees this potential love interest as “cool.”

Couldn’t fight to save your life but you look so cool
 Camo jacket robbing corner stores

This “Crush” is rebellious.
He’s robbing corner stores, thinking he’ll get away with it, but in the end he’s defeated.

He couldn’t fight hard enough, but the fact that he even attempted to steal in the first place is impressive and enticing to Ethel. She’s awestruck by him, even though he lost the fight.
She acknowledges that he lost, she’s not oblivious, but she is infatuated by his attempts.
Hard odds to beat when you’re on all fours

Her Crush lost the fight as he was caught trying to steal. He’s knocked on the ground, on all fours, potentially being beaten. Ethel certainly acknowledges that he lost, but ultimately that  does phase Ethel, as she has rose-colored glasses on, and still sees this potential love interest as “cool.”

Couldn’t fight to save your life but you look so cool
 (You know it, you know it, you know)
 Camo jacket robbing corner stores

This “Crush” is rebellious.
He’s robbing corner stores, thinking he’ll get away with it, but in the end he’s defeated.

He couldn’t fight hard enough, but the fact that he even attempted to steal in the first place is impressive and enticing to Ethel. She’s awestruck by him, even though he lost the fight.
She acknowledges that he lost, she’s not oblivious, but she is infatuated by his attempts.

Oh, I’d rather be with you
 Oh, I’d rather be with you
 ’Cause good men die too so I’d rather be with you

Everybody dies, including the good men.
It’s the cycle of life, so why should she waste time friending for a “Good man” when this “Crush” is more enticing.

The bad can feel good in the moment, so she will take the risk of her crush or lover dying faster, as it’s a thrill.

Good men die, just like bad boys, so she’d rather take the risk and stay with the enticing bad man, as they’ll all die in the end anyway.
Good men die too so I’d rather be with you

As previously acknowledged, this “Crush” may be a little bit of a bad man. Robbing corner stores, keeping guns in lockers, etc.
“Bad Boys” get into trouble, and the kind of trouble this “Crush” gets into is risky, and he might just die someday if he’s irresponsible enough.
Ethel in this line is saying that everybody dies, including the good men. It’s the cycle of life, so why waste time friending for a “Good man” when this “Crush” is more enticing.
Good men die, just like bad boys, so she’d rather take the risk and stay with the enticing bad man, as they’ll all die in the end anyway.

search_results.lyrics:
A House in Nebraska Lyrics[Verse 1]
Labored breaths and bed sores
Sing it to me all day long
When the aching sound of silence
Used to be our favorite song
You and me against the world
You were my man and I your girl
We had nothing except each other
You were my whole world
But then the day came
And you were up and gone
[Chorus]
And I still call home that house in Nebraska
Where we found each other on a dirty mattress on the second floor
Where the world was empty
Save you and I
Where you came and I laughed, and you left, and I cried
Where you told me even if we died tonight, that I'd die yours

[Verse 2]
These dirt roads are empty
The ones we paved ourselves
Your mama calls me sometimes
To see if I'm doing well
And I lie to her
And say that I'm doing fine
When really I'd kill myself
To hold you one more time
And it hurts to miss you
But it's worse to know
That I'm the reason
You won't come home

[Chorus]
But I still call home that house in Nebraska
Where we found each other on a dirty mattress on the second floor
(When I needed you, and I need you still)
Where the world was empty
Save you and I
Where you came and I laughed, and you left, and I cried
Where you told me even if we died tonight, that I'd die yours
(So I died there under you, every night, all night)
You might also like[Verse 3]
You know, I still wait at the edge of town
Praying straight to God that maybe you’ll come back around
I cry every day, and the bottles make it worse
'Cause you were the only one I was never scared to tell I hurt
And I found photographs of our school, on the day we met
I thought that you were so beautiful, it was love, I guess
And you might never come back home, and I may never sleep at night
But God, I just hope you're doing fine out there, I just pray that you're all right

[Outro]
And I feel so alone
And I feel so alone out here
I feel so alone
And I feel so alone out here
And I feel so alone without you
I'm so alone out here
I feel so alone, I feel so alone
I'm so alone out here without you, baby
(I'm alone)3Embed

description.plain: Ethel thinks of her ex-lover, Willoughby Tucker, who left town before the events of the album. She remembers the good times they shared and longs for him to come back home. She visits the abandoned house they would spend time in, imagining it was their own, somewhere far away from their hometown of Shady Grove, Alabama.

annotatable.link_title: A House in Nebraska by Ethel Cain
annotatable.title: A House in Nebraska

body.plain: Ethel thinks of her ex-lover, Willoughby Tucker, who left town before the events of the album. She remembers the good times they shared and longs for him to come back home. She visits the abandoned house they would spend time in, imagining it was their own, somewhere far away from their hometown of Shady Grove, Alabama.

annotations: ’Cause you were the only one I was never scared to tell I hurt
Ethel was so connected to him, that she felt as if he would never judge her for her vulnerability.
But I still call home that house in Nebraska
The contrast in calling an abandoned house home may suggest the emptiness that Ethel feels after her lover’s disappearance
Where you told me even if we died tonight, that I’d die yours
Even in her idyllic image of happiness, she is still someone’s property. Whether she was her father’s daughter or her partner’s partner.
(So I died there under you, every night, all night)

“under you” could imply sex or some kind of power dynamic where she was under will’s control. And the use of died implies negative connotations such as again a toxic power dynamic or situation.

Died could also connect to religious connotations of virginity.
I cry every day, and the bottles make it worse

“the bottles” is alcohol. She’s saying that the alcohol makes her feelings of depression and loss worse.

This line is a direct reference to utilizing alcohol as a means of soothing herself, which circles back to the previous track “American Teenager” where she speaks about using alcohol in order to deliver sermons in her father’s place.
But God, I just hope you’re doing fine out there, I just pray that you’re all right

In contrast to the later lyric ‘God loves you, but enough to save you’ from Sun Bleached Flies, Ethel still has faith in religion to protect the man she loves. In an ironic turn of events, it’s also the man she loves who kills her while her prayers to be saved are ignored. It suggests a naivety about Ethel.
You were my whole world

“Everybody but his mama just calls him “Will”, though, as in “will do just about anything”. They were right; I can’t remember a time when that boy wasn’t getting his ass chewed out by his daddy but I was sweet on him for it. I’ve been sweet on him, long as I can remember.”


from an alternate Tumblr account
Labored breaths and bed sores
Difficulty breathing and sores caused by laying/sitting in one place for a long time depict imagery of illness

You know, I still wait at the edge of town
 Praying straight to God that maybe you’ll come back around

This phrasing may be a reference to Bruce Springsteen’s song “Reason to Believe,” in which verse two details a woman waiting at the edge of a road for her lover to return to her. This song is from Springsteen’s album Nebraska, which shares not just geographic but thematic elements with Preacher’s Daughter. Cain’s music has often been compared to Springsteen’s; both artists’ work interrogate an idealized and unachievable American identity. The titular song off Springsteen’s album details the real-life serial killings of Charles Starkweather and his female accomplice. Springsteen also explores intergenerational trauma on the album, and “Reason to Believe,” in particular, explores the persistence of faith in the face of hardship. It may also be referencing his famous song “Darkness on the Edge of Town,” in which he explores American cultural alienation.

Where the world was empty
 Save you and I

Sometimes you really feel as if nothing else in the world was happening when you’re talking to someone you’re in love with. I personally think that Ethel or Hayden genuinely thought that nothing else existed beyond the walls of that house of Nebraska when she was spending time with Willoughby.

description.plain:
Under the influence of Isaiah’s drugs, Ethel begins to hallucinate. She confronts the darkness.

The song name is inspired from Alighieri’s Divine Comedy [specifically Dante’s Inferno] Ptolemea, named after Ptolemy, is a circle of Hell in which the traitorous reside. Maybe this is a reference to Ethel abandoning her family and faith – only to be met with a wrath far worse.

song.embed_content: Read “Ptolemaea” by Ethel Cain on Genius
song.title: Ptolemaea

body.plain:
Under the influence of Isaiah’s drugs, Ethel begins to hallucinate. She confronts the darkness.

The song name is inspired from Alighieri’s Divine Comedy [specifically Dante’s Inferno] Ptolemea, named after Ptolemy, is a circle of Hell in which the traitorous reside. Maybe this is a reference to Ethel abandoning her family and faith – only to be met with a wrath far worse.

annotations: Blessed be the children, each and every one come to know their god through some senseless act of violence

This line seems to refer to Ethel’s father. Since he was the town’s Preacher, he was Ethel’s main introduction to religion and instilled his religious knowledge into her at a young age, hence “come to know their god”.

However, we know her father was also abusive towards Ethel. This disrupted her lens she viewed religion through and no doubt tainted it, adding to one of the many reasons she ran away from home in the first place.
Daddy’s left and Mama won’t come home

In the Preachers Daughter storyline, Joseph and Vera Cain are Ethel’s parents. Joseph being the preacher and Vera being the titular Preacher’s Wife of Cain’s upcoming album.

Ethel has decided to run away from home with Isaiah, and in her state of drug induced delusion she’s referring to Isaiah as her father, and he’s left her in the basement, and her confusion as to where her mother has gone proves to the listener that Ethel really is losing grip on her sense of reality. She does not know where she is and is looking for her parents when in reality, the only person that can save her is Isaiah and he’s not going to do that.
I am the face of love’s rage

i like to think of this lyric as a way of ethel saying she is “the face of loves rage” because of all the abuse she’s experienced in her life from her father to logan to now isaiah, it’s almost as if she’s given up and succumbed to the abuse she’s endured reflecting that she is nothing more than her abuse and trauma almost as if when people think of “loves rage” or abusive relationships they see her. although im not 100% sure who exactly is saying this line and it could possibly be isaiah saying it i still like to think of it this way.
Hiding from something I cannot stop

Could be referring to the threat of religion and how because she is a preacher’s daughter she cannot escape her family and the associated religious guilt in the same way that “Jesus can always reject his father. But he cannot escape his mother’s blood”

I am no good nor evil, simply I am, and I have come to take what is mine
 I was there in the dark when you spilled your first blood
 I am here now as you run from me still
 Run then, child
 You can’t hide from me forever

This is death. Who comes to get everyone, the good and the bad. It was there when Ethel spilled up her first blood, a sign that her life was slipping away. Death says she can run, but she cannot hide, because death is inevitable.
Whore mothers,

“One conclusion I had over the course of this record is that your mother might be the source of all your problems, but she’s also a victim of things that happened before you were even thought up. There are no good guys or bad guys in real life, just deeply flawed people."
Bound to suffering eternal through the sins of their fathers committed long before their conception

Anhedönia speaks of this in a prior interview, when discussing Inbred, an album released in 2021. And it’s exactly that. Suffering weaves itself into the family genealogy, in a dizzying, inbred, distorted way. Actions undone from fathers years ago fester into the future.
Stop, stop, stop, stop

After her final “stop,” Ethel’s voice is drowned out by another male vocalist’s. This could be an auditory metaphor, a sort of indication that Ethel’s fate is already decided. Her fight is nearly over and she is succumbing to Isaiah’s abuse.
I am the face of love’s rage

Typically, hallucinations are a simulacrum of reality: untrue, unfaithful. But, ironically, these hallucinations, albeit hauntingly dark, provide a semblance of truth to Ethel: that her lover has betrayed her. The tides have turned at this point in the track: Ethel is no longer Ptolemy the Traitor, it’s Isaiah instead.

Saying I’m the one, he’s gonna take me
 I’m on fire, I’m on fire, I’m on fire
 Suffering is nigh, drawing to me
 Calling me the one, I’m the white light
 Beautiful, finite

As the lyrics follow, Isaiah acknowledges Ethel as a pure, mythologised entity, maybe due to her strict Christian upbringing. However, the purity that Ethel dons is fallible and Isaiah is entranced by this. Religiously, saints and prophets have been martyred and have suffered cruel deaths, and it is alluded that Ethel herself will fall under the same fate.

description.plain: Murdered and cannibalized by Isaiah, Ethel says her final goodbye to her mother from beyond the grave.

song.embed_content: Read “Strangers” by Ethel Cain on Genius
song.title: Strangers

body.plain: Murdered and cannibalized by Isaiah, Ethel says her final goodbye to her mother from beyond the grave.

annotations: We’ll make love in your attic all night

isiah sees cannibalism as a form of love?
he still only sees ethel for her body.
this “love” is an extreme way of representing their relationship— a one sided exchange only he benefits from. ethel is dead, it’s impossible for her to derive any pleasure from this.
You devour like smoked bovine hide

Bovine refers to cattle, and Isiah is eating her as if she is beef jerky (smoked bovine hide – beef jerky???). The word “devour” also has interesting connotations; of ferality, desperation and messiness.

I tried to be good
 Am I no good?
 Am I no good?
 Am I no good?

These lines hold a double meaning. One is Ethel reflecting on her past and saying how she tried to be good in life, yet still met a gruesome and untimely death. The other is directed at Isaiah, asking him if she is any good when he is cannibalizing her.

”God is telling you and I there is death, for all of us
 But then we find that the scriptures also tell us that we have a great promise, that there is a better place for those who believe in the lord Jesus Christ”

According to Hayden in a Tumblr ask, this audio of a preacher’s sermon is sampled from the 1995 video recording of her great-grandmother’s funeral. A different sample from the same source appears at the beginning of Family Tree (Intro), the first track on the album.
You’re so handsome, walking over to me now
Isaiah is walking over to the body of Ethel, and her thoughts about him here are detached but show that she still loves him, despite what he did.

Found you just to tell you that I made it real far
 And that I never blamed you for loving me the way that you did

This could be read as Ethel meeting her father in the afterlife. Interestingly, given the religious themes of the album, this could be either Heaven  or Hell. Given her father’s abuse of Ethel, and her innocence, it seems weird that he would be in Heaven or that she would be in Hell. It suggests that possibly everyone ends up in the same afterlife and that there is no Heaven or Hell, reinforcing the themes of blurred morals found throughout the album.

However, this could also be Ethel’s last words to her mother in a possible spiritual form. She wants to assure her mother that her circumstances and death is not her fault and that she loves her.

In your basement, I grow cold
 Thinking back to what I was always told
 “Don’t talk to strangers or you might fall in love”

Ethel, now dead, has no control over what has happened to her. Her body lies in his basement, left to regret falling in love because she simply has to believe that that is has ended up where she has. She blames herself for the things that have happened to her because people warned her not to talk to strangers.
Freezer bride, your sweet divine
Isaiah put Ethel in the preserve her body before he was ready to indulge.
If I’m turning in your stomach and I’m making you feel sick

Ethel doesn’t have a grave to turn in. She is in Isaiah’s stomach, which is her grave. The phrase “turning in their grave” is usually meant to mean that a passed person would disapproves of something.
Ethel hates that she will never see her mother again and how sick she will feel not knowing what happened to her daughter after she ran away.

There is also the physical meaning as Isaiah has a food poisoning from Ethel’s body, causing the feeling of her turning in his stomach and making him feel ill. She finds humour in her death yet again.
How funny, I never considered myself tough

Ethel’s dead body is eaten by Isaiah, and here, she uses a double meaning of the word ‘tough’… thinking back to her life on Earth and how she never thought of herself as strong-willed or resilient (tough), yet, the meat of her body is firm and stiff and hard (tough) to chew/swallow by Isaiah… she finds comedy in the fact that Isaiah is now finding her body tough to chew, when, during her life, he used her apparent lack of emotional toughness for his own malicious gain.

description.plain: In Heaven, Ethel makes peace with her death, and reflects on her life, her family, and the man she never stopped loving, Willoughby.

song.embed_content: Read “Sun Bleached Flies” by Ethel Cain on Genius
song.full_title: Sun Bleached Flies by Ethel Cain
song.title: Sun Bleached Flies

annotatable.link_title: Sun Bleached Flies by Ethel Cain
annotatable.title: Sun Bleached Flies

body.plain: In Heaven, Ethel makes peace with her death, and reflects on her life, her family, and the man she never stopped loving, Willoughby.

annotations: Singing if it’s meant to be then it will be
The singing could be a reference to the church choirs, and the sentiment “if it’s meant to be then it will be” has feelings of faithfulness and hope. Perhaps Ethel has made peace with her faith?
So, baby girl, good luck taking care of yourself
This line is Ethel, from the afterlife, speaking to the listener, warning them not to repeat the mistakes of the past.

So I said fine, ’cause that’s how my daddy raised me
 If they strike once then you just hit ’em twice as hard
 But in the end, if I bend under the weight that they gave me
 Then this heart would break and fall as twice as far

Ethel’s instinct in the face of danger or disrespect is to fight back, but she realises now that doing so would only repeat the cycle of abuse that she’s faced, and it would come back to bite her even harder.
But I still feel like they all know, and that’s why I can never go back home

Going back home would be admitting defeat. Ethel doesn’t want to go back to the life she lived, she has transcended the life she had and the community it was in. the shame she knows she would face is too much to face so she would rather live in this hell she finds herself in

But I don’t mind ’cause that’s how my daddy raised me (How my daddy raised me)
 If they strike once then you just hit ’em twice as hard
 But I always knew that in the end no one was coming to save me
 So I just prayed and I keep praying and praying and praying

Having been brought up in a christian family, her father been a deacon. Cain applies juxtaposition on the famous Luke 6:29 which states,

If someone slaps you on one cheek, turn to them the other also.

Cain continues to express her contradictions of organized religion with saying that she always knew that the promised Redeemer/Savior was never going to come for her despite being taught so in her religion. So she just kept on praying in her disbelief.
The more it hurts, the less it shows

Usually, when someone is going through a low point in their life, it is (most times not under their own accord) shown the absolute opposite.

But in Ethel’s case, her vulnerability has let shown her scars given by her past, and she’s afraid of change or the wild switch of perspective that can fall over her own.

What I wouldn’t give to be in Church this Sunday
 Listening to the choir, so heartfelt, all singing
Though Ethel resented the church, while in Heaven and away from home she wishes to be back in the safety and comfort that being in church provided.

Sun bleached flies sitting in the windowsill
 Waiting for the day they escape
 They talk all about that money and how their babies are always changing while they’re breathing in the poison of the paint

Ethel compares sun bleached flies resting on a windowsill to a Christian Mother, waiting for a day they are able to escape. Talking about their children while the children are being exposed to toxic behaviors described as poisonous paint.
God loves you, but not enough to save you
In an interview with Meghan Garvey, Ethel Cain talks about how this statement would usually be paired with “the most rancid evil shit”:
I forgive it all as it comes back to me (Back to me)

Ethel let’s go of the cycle of abuse she’s been through, and refuses to perpetuate it, deciding to forgive the ones who did her harm, so no one, including her has to carry the weight of these traumas anymore.

description.plain: Closing out Act One of the album, Hard Times sees Ethel reflecting on the sexual abuse she endured from her father when she was a child, and the complicated feelings she has in regards to him.

song.embed_content: Read “Hard Times” by Ethel Cain on Genius
song.title: Hard Times

body.plain: Closing out Act One of the album, Hard Times sees Ethel reflecting on the sexual abuse she endured from her father when she was a child, and the complicated feelings she has in regards to him.

songs.full_title: Ethel Cain - Hard Times (Traducción al Español) by Genius Traducciones al Español
songs.title: Ethel Cain - Hard Times (Traducción al Español)
songs.title_with_featured: Ethel Cain - Hard Times (Traducción al Español)

translation_songs.title: Ethel Cain - Hard Times (Traducción al Español)

annotations: I’ll make pretend

This lyric is twofold. On one hand, it speaks to her desire that her and her father’s relationship could have been different. But it also serves as another motif of innocence and childhood by evoking pretend play, an important form of children’s social and cognitive development.
Lay it on me

This line has a double meaning.
The phrase “Lay it on me” is slang for “presenting or revealing something to someone thoroughly or heavily,” in reference to the concept many women face about their objectification at a young age.

This also is literal, and saying something literally is ‘laid’ on her body.

Tell me a story
 About how it ends
 Where you’re still the good guy

Possibly alluding to how her entire town of Shady Grove still tells “stories” of how good of a man Rev. Joseph Cain was, even after his passing.

It’s possible that her father actually blackmailed Ethel into this narrative as well, as it’s common within abuse cases, especially CSA cases where the victim is too young to understand what’s going on, much like Ethel was at the time.

He may have told her these “stories” where he paints himself as a good man, and tells her that it’s all out of love, but if she dare tell a soul, she won’t be believed.

Ethel doesn’t like this story, because it ends with her as the victim and him as a victor, when in reality he should have been held accountable for his secret sins.

I was too young
 To notice
 That some types of love could be bad

A young Ethel sadly mistook her fathers staring as a loving, wholesome look.

Part of growing up is learning that not everyone has your best interest, but in Ethel’s case, that unfortunately included her father.

She may have thought he was doing these things out of love, when really it was sadistic and “bad.”

In the corner
 On my birthday
 You watched me

Ethel was too young to notice the way her father stares at her. This line has a dark and ominous undertone, it could be so innocent had it not been in the context it’s actually in.

Unfortunately in this context, her father is preying on her, watching her lustfully, instead of lovingly.

Children’s birthdays are usually regarded as happy celebrations, where the parents praise and celebrate another year of their babies life.
(This is potentially alluded to in the lines where she states how she is in fact unhappy)

But for Ethel, her birthday was unknowingly preyed upon by her father, who watched her secretly with lust in his eyes instead of the wholesome pride families are supposed to show on their child’s special day.

Hide me there
 Under the leaves

This is a striking line, detailing the tragic secret abuse she endured at the hands of someone she was told to trust.

Ethel’s father hid her under the leaves and abused her, much like how his sin is seemingly forever hidden.

’Cause I hate this story
 Where happiness ends
 And dies with you

Ethel expresses her distaste with this man in power taking advantage of her.

She knows it is not fair that her story gets to continue without any justice or “happiness,”
while this man, presumably her father, gets to keep his dirty secrets even while in the grave, and is not punished by his adoring community for it.

He had died when she was 10, and this song states that she was nine during the abuse.

He gets his happiness and pleasure, and still gets praised even long after his death by the community.
On the flip side, Ethel has to live with this secret and shame, all the while hearing nonstop endless praise and adoration for her father.

knowing what he did to her and who he really was behind the church scene, and Ethel hates that feeling of knowing the secret, but also knowing that if she dare spoke out, she would not be believed, or she would be shamed.

I thought good guys get to be happy
 I’m not happy
 I am poison in the water and unhappy

This seems like a subtle but intentional way to describe the character of Ethel Cain as transgender, which has been supported by Hayden herself. The common phrase “good guys” is used to refer to the protagonist herself, but she quickly follows herself up by referring to herself as a “little girl”.

Additionally, many victims of sexual abuse feel they are at fault and deserve the bad things that happen to them. This could shed light as to why she declares herself as “poison in the water”. Many abuse victims also frequently return to their abusers for reasons of emotional or material dependence. This is likely demonstrated in the final line “little girl who needs her daddy real bad”.
(It’s just the way that you are)

It’s not unheard of that survivors of abuse will sometimes make excuses for their abusers and try to rationalize their behavior as a defense mechanism. It is also not uncommon for abuse survivors to the actions of their abusers justified to them by others. Though we’d like t believe that cases of SA and CSA are treated with the utmost seriousness, it is not at all uncommon for cases to be denied, ignored, and swept under the rug especially if the abuser in question is in a position of authority like a parent or guardian or the town preacher
(Bleeding whenever you want)

According to RAINN, CSA can result in trauma to the genital area such as unexplained bleeding, bruising, or blood on the sheets, underwear, or other clothing. Ethel’s father abused her so often that these symptoms have become common place

description.plain: After Ethel arrives in California with Isaiah, he begins to pimp her out in the back of strip clubs and feed her drugs on the regular. Ethel begins to lose sense of reality. The title refers to Charles Dana Gibson and the women he famously drew, often considered the pinnacle of American beauty standards.

song.embed_content: Read “Gibson Girl” by Ethel Cain on Genius
song.title: Gibson Girl

body.plain: After Ethel arrives in California with Isaiah, he begins to pimp her out in the back of strip clubs and feed her drugs on the regular. Ethel begins to lose sense of reality. The title refers to Charles Dana Gibson and the women he famously drew, often considered the pinnacle of American beauty standards.

annotations:
Where I can be immoral
 In a stranger’s lap

What Ethel’s doing doesn’t just “feel good” because sex brings pleasure, but the pleasure also stems from the fact that Ethel can revel in the glory of doing something she’s not supposed to. By being"immoral", she rebels against the values that her father and her father’s community have instilled inside of her, which she’s longed to escape (as seen in the previous song Thoroughfare). She’s seeing the world beyond the narrow confines of her hometown and she thinks that it “feels good”.

These lines can be interpreted as Ethel’s own words or ones that Isaiah put in her.

”Baby, if it feels good
 Then it can’t be bad”

tw // grooming & gaslighting

I was listening to this song with a friend who had recently been a victim of grooming, when we got to this part she told me (under a heavy layer of irony) that she had “heard this before.”

if it feels good, then it can’t leave lasting physical, psychological, emotional, mental damage and trauma, right?

Ethel is being gaslighted and taken advantage of, she’s being told that since sex is pleasurable, she should enjoy it and not think about how the circumstances she’s in – how messed up and dangerous (physically and psychologically) it is to be pimped like she is, how Isaac is taking advantage of her, how he uses her and throws her away because in the end, she doesn’t matter to him, and the marks or “crosses” that it could leave on her body & psyche.

Depending on the groomer, “if it feels good, then it can’t be bad” can be said in a reassuring or dismissive tone, to deceive the victim or the groomer themselves, but either way the message is the same: “Those thoughts are irrational. You’re overthinking. Enjoy it for what it can be.”

search_results.title: Thoroughfare
search_results.lyrics:
Thoroughfare Lyrics[Verse 1]
You fell in love with America when you were twelve years old
And by seventeen, you knew you had to see it all
You loved your dad and the love he had for your mother, so
You had to get out and go chasin' its sweet call

[Verse 2]
I met you there in Texas somewhere on the thoroughfare
On the side of the road in some torn-up clothes with a pistol in my pocket
I didn't trust no one, but you said, "Baby, don't run, I'll take you anywhere"
So I hopped right in, outta luck to spend, and at least your truck beats walking
[Chorus]
And you said, "Hey, do you wanna see thе west with me?
'Cause lovе's out there and I can't leave it be"
And I said, "Honey, love's never meant much to me
But I'll come with you if you're sure it's what you need"

[Verse 3]
So we made off for California
To find your lover, drivin' day and night
And every small town diner
Saw our faces at least once or twice
But in these motel rooms
I started to see you differently, oh
'Cause for the first time since I was a child
I could see a man who wasn't angry

[Verse 4]
And he said, "It's been a long damn time since I left Florida
No one left to leave and no one left to love
But now that I met you, I finally know just where I'm headin'"
And we found heaven in time where your western sunshine
Met my deep southern wet
And you got lost in it and yet you found yourself
Hard-pressed for air and sweatin'

[Chorus]
And you said, "Hey, do you wanna see the west with me?
(Do you wanna see the west with me?)
'Cause love's out there and I can't leave it be"
(I can't leave it, I can't leave it)
And I said, "Honey, love's never meant that much to me
(Nothing much)
But I'll come with you if you're sure it's what you need"
You might also like[Bridge]
And once we reached the coast, you said, "End of the line
We finally reached the edge after all this time
I didn't find my love, but I still made it this far without it"
And then you turned to me and stared into me deep
And said, "Well, maybe not 'cause look at what I've got
You might not be my love, but, baby, I doubt it"

[Chorus]
And you said, "Hey, do you wanna see the west with me?
'Cause love's out there and I can't leave it be"
(I can't leave it, I can't leave it)
And I said, "Honey, love's never meant that much to me
But I'll come with you if you're sure it's what you need"

[Outro]
'Cause in your pickup truck with all of your dumb luck is the only place I think I'd ever wanna be

[Tambourine- and scat-led jam session]3Embed

description.plain: Act Two of the album begins with Thoroughfare. Ethel, having run away from home, meets charming  Isaiah, who offers her a ride. Together, they drive from Texas to California. Over the course of their trip, they find themselves attracted to one another.

song.embed_content: Read “Thoroughfare” by Ethel Cain on Genius
song.title: Thoroughfare

body.plain: Act Two of the album begins with Thoroughfare. Ethel, having run away from home, meets charming  Isaiah, who offers her a ride. Together, they drive from Texas to California. Over the course of their trip, they find themselves attracted to one another.

annotations: You might not be my love, but, baby, I doubt it”
The real love might be the friends we made along the way.

’Cause for the first time since I was a child
 I could see a man who wasn’t angry

if you’re raised with an angry man in your house, there will always be an angry man in your house

from “Cut,” by Catherine Lacey (The New Yorker, 2019)

The theme of generational trauma reappears throughout Preacher’s Daughter. Given what we’ve learned about Ethel’s father in “Hard Times” and her tumultuous relationship with Logan, as detailed in “Western Nights,” we start to understand how Ethel’s traumatic upbringing influences her future relationships, even after her father’s death.

Although this song gives an overall sense of hope for Ethel’s future, this line foreshadows what would ultimately be the cause of her death.
I met you there in Texas somewhere on the thoroughfare

According to a fictional interview by Teeth Magazine, Ethel was last seen in Arlington, Texas.
Isaiah met Ethel “somewhere” in Texas, and she had been missing since.
We finally reached the edge after all this time
The vastness of the ocean can sometimes make you feel like you’re standing at the end of the entire world.
And he said, ”It’s been a long damn time since I left Florida
Isaiah is from Florida, Ethel is from Alabama. They meet in Texas and drive to California together.

And we found heaven in time where your western sunshine
 Met my deep southern wet
 And you got lost in it and yet you found yourself
 Hard-pressed for air and sweatin’
Ethel and Isaiah find themselves in a sexual relationship over the course of their road trip.

search_results.full_title: Morning Elvis (Live At Denver Ball Arena) by Florence + the Machine (Ft. Ethel Cain)
search_results.title: Morning Elvis (Live At Denver Ball Arena)
search_results.title_with_featured: Morning Elvis (Live At Denver Ball Arena) (Ft. Ethel Cain)
search_results.lyrics:
Morning Elvis (Live At Denver Ball Arena) Lyrics[Verse 1: Florence Welch, Ethel Cain, Both]
When they dressed me and they put me on a plane to Memphis, well
I never got to see Elvis
I just sweated it out in a motel room
But I think the king would've understood
Why I never made it to Graceland
Bathroom tiles were cool against my hand
I pressed my forehead to the floor and I prayed for a trapdoor
I've been here many times before
But I've never made it to Graceland
[Chorus: Florence Welch & Ethel Cain]
And if I make it to the mornin'
I shoulda come with a warnin'
And if I make it to the stage
I'll show you what it means
To be saved

[Verse 2: Ethel Cain, Florence Welch, Both]
Well, pick me up in New Orleans
Pinned in a bathroom stall
Pick me up above my body
Press my corpse against the wall
I told the band to leave without me
I, I'll get the next flight
And I'll see you all with Elvis
If I don't survive the night

[Chorus: Florence Welch & Ethel Cain]
If I make it to the mornin'
I shoulda come with a warnin'
And if I make it to the stage
I'll show you what it means
To be saved

[Bridge: Ethel Cain, Florence Welch]
And after every tour, I swear I'll quit
It's over, boys, now this is it
But the call, it always comes
The songs like children beggin' to be born
But I guess I got my wish
But anything, anything, anything but this
See Florence + the Machine LiveGet tickets as low as $74You might also like[Chorus: Both, Florence Welch, Ethel Cain]
If I make it to the mornin'
I shoulda come with a warnin'
If I make it to the stage
I'll show you what it means
To be saved
Well, you know I'm still afraid
I'm still crazy and I'm still scared
But if I make it to the stage
I'll show you what it means
To be spared
To be spared
To be spared
To be spared
To be spared

[Spoken Outro: Florence Welch]
Ethel CainEmbed
